sentences.sentence: Then he drew his sword( 剑 ) and gave each of the giants( 巨人 ) a few cuts to the chest( 胸膛 ).
He went back to the horsemen( 骑手 ) and said,
“It is done; I have killed both of them.
But it was a hard fight. In the struggle( 斗争 ) they took up trees to defend( 保护 ) themselves.
But it was no use; they were fighting a man who can kill seven at one blow.”
“Then are you not wounded( 受伤的 )?” asked the horsemen.
“Not at all!” answered the tailor( 裁缝 ). “You can see that they have not harmed even a hair on my head.”
The horsemen still would not believe it, and rode into the wood to see.
There they found the giants covered in their blood, and all about them were lying the trees that had been torn( 撕碎 ) out of the ground.
The little tailor then claimed the promised reward( 回报 ).
But the King now regretted having made his offer, and tried to find another way to get rid( 摆脱 ) of this troublesome hero.
“Before you can have my daughter and half my kingdom,” said he to the tailor, “you must show us again how brave you are.
In the wood lives a unicorn( 独角兽 ) who does great damage( 危害 ): you must capture( 俘获 ) him.”
“Why should a unicorn scare( （使）害怕 ) me when two giants do not? Seven at one blow! That is my way,” was the tailor’s answer.
So, taking a rope and an ax( 斧头 ) with him, he went out into the wood.
The unicorn soon came out and attacked him, as if to kill him as fast as possible.
“Softly, softly,” said he, “most haste, less speed( 欲速则不达 ).”
He remained standing in front of a tree until the animal was very near, then suddenly hid behind the tree.
The unicorn ran with all his strength against the tree and stuck his horn( 角 ) so deep into the trunk( 树干 ) that he could not get it out again, and so was taken.
“Now I have you,” said the tailor, coming out from behind the tree.
He put the rope round the unicorn’s neck, used the ax to free the unicorn’s horn from the tree, and brought the unicorn back to the King.
The King still did not want to give him the promised reward, and set him a third task to do.
Before the wedding( 婚礼 ) could take place, the tailor was to catch a wild boar( 野猪 ) which had done a great deal of damage( 危害 ) in the wood.
The huntsmen( 猎人 ) were to accompany( 陪伴 ) him.
“All right,” said the tailor, “this is child’s play.”
But he did not take the huntsmen into the wood—which made them happy, because the wild boar had killed and wounded( （使）受伤 ) many of them before.
When the boar caught sight of( 忽然看到 )f the tailor, it ran at him with foaming( 暴怒的 ) mouth and sharp( 尖利的 ), shining tusks( 獠牙 ).
But the nimble( 机敏的 ) tailor rushed into a nearby church, and jumped quickly out of a window on the other side.
The boar ran after him, and when it got inside, the tailor ran around and shut the door after it.
The boar was trapped( 被困住 ), because it was too big and heavy to jump out of the window as the tailor had done.
Then the little tailor called the huntsmen( 猎人 ) so that they might see the prisoner( 俘虏 ) with their own eyes.
Then he went to the king, who now had to keep his promise, whether he wanted to or not.
He gave the tailor his daughter in marriage, and half his kingdom.
He was not happy about it—but if he had known that the great warrior( 勇士 ) was only a little tailor, he would have been even more upset( 生气的 ).
So the wedding( 婚礼 ) was celebrated with great splendor( 奢华 ), but with little joy( 喜悦 )—on the King’s part, at least.
One night the King’s daughter heard her husband talking in his sleep and saying,
“Now boy, fix the hole in these trousers, or I will hit you with my measuring stick( 量尺 )!”
Now she knew that her husband was just a common tailor.
She went to her father the next morning and told him everything.
She begged( 乞求 ) him to free her from this man, who was not worthy to marry a princess( 公主 ).
The king told her not to worry, and said,

“Tonight leave your bedroom( 卧室 ) door open. My guards will stand outside, and when he is asleep they will come in and bind( 捆绑 ) him and carry him off to a ship. Then he shall be sent to the other side of the world.”
So the wife felt happier.
But one of the King’s servants, who had been listening all the while, went to the little tailor and told him the whole plan.
“I shall put a stop to all this,” said he.
At night he lay down as usual on bed.
When his wife thought that he was asleep, she got up, opened the door, and lay down again.
But the little tailor pretended( 假装 ) to be talking in his sleep:
“Now boy, fix the hole in these trousers, or I will hit you with my measuring stick!
I have killed seven at one blow, killed two giants( 巨人 ), caught a unicorn, and taken a wild boar—why should I fear all those men who are right now standing outside my room?”
And when the guards heard the tailor say this, they were afraid.
They ran away as fast as they could, and none of them dared( 敢 ) to attack him.
And so the little tailor finally became a king.
